title: Live updates: Israel-Iran ceasefire appears to hold as Trump heads to NATO summit
description: Iranian and Israeli officials said they would respect the terms of the ceasefire if the other side did too.
author: Andrew Jeong, Niha Masih, Frances Vinall, Abbie Cheeseman, Victoria Craw, Angie Orellana Hernandez, Mikhail Klimentov, Cate Brown, Sammy Westfall
byline: Andrew Jeong, Niha Masih, Frances Vinall, Abbie Cheeseman, Victoria Craw, Angie Orellana Hernandez, Mikhail Klimentov, Cate Brown, Sammy Westfall, Katrina Northrop, Lyric Li, Brian Perlman, Janice Kai Chen, Vivian Ho, Washington Post staff, Warren P. Strobel, John Hudson, Karen DeYoung, Dan Lamothe, Elahe Izadi, Steve Hendrix, Susannah George, Claire Parker, Alon Rom, Lior Soroka, Marianna Sotomayor, Emily Davies, Mariana Alfaro, Theodoric Meyer, Mohamad El Chamaa, Heba Farouk Mahfouz, Alex Horton, Meg Kelly, Joyce Sohyun Lee, Nilo Tabrizy, Evan Hill, Dylan Moriarty, Jarrett Ley, Patrick Svitek, Andrew deGrandpre, Natalia Abbakumova, Kate Brady, Souad Mekhennet, Yeganeh Torbati, Heidi Levine, Kareem Fahim, Gerry Shih, Rachel Pannett
excerpt: Iranian and Israeli officials said they would respect the terms of the ceasefire if the other side did too.
text: A ceasefire between Israel and Iran appears to be holding, after an initial shaky period in which both sides accused each other of violations, drawing admonishment from President Donald Trump. “Both Israel and Iran wanted to stop the War, equally!” Trump wrote in a post on Truth Social on Tuesday, en route to a NATO summit in the Netherlands. “It was my great honor to Destroy All Nuclear facilities & capability, and then, STOP THE WAR!” An initial U.S. intelligence report cast doubt on Trump’s claims, however, assessing that U.S. airstrikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities set Tehran’s program back by months but did not eliminate it, two people familiar with the report told the Post.Where things stand: Ceasefire, latest strikes and the war’s death tollReturn to menuIsrael and Iran have publicly committed to upholding a ceasefire that President Donald Trump announced Monday evening, with both sides casting it as a victory to their people.Trump told Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that the United States was done using its military to help Israel in its war with Iran, according to a senior White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive and private conversations.In the hours after the ceasefire had been expected to go into effect early Tuesday, Israel and Iran accused each other of violating the agreement, drawing admonishment from Trump. Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz accused Iran of firing a wave of missiles toward Israel and said he instructed the military to “respond forcefully.” A message posted on the Telegram channel of Iran’s state broadcaster denied the claim of a missile launch. Iran then accused Israel of launching three waves of attacks shortly after Trump said the truce had gone into effect. Netanyahu’s office later said Israel would refrain from additional attacks.A preliminary U.S. intelligence report assessed that U.S. airstrikes against Iran’s nuclear facilities set Tehran’s program back by months but did not eliminate it like Trump had announced, two people familiar with the report told The Washington Post.The International Atomic Energy Agency director general Rafael Mariano Grossi said there were no reports of increased off-site radiation levels around the nuclear facilities.Israel and Iran launched blistering attacks on each other as a deadline for the truce loomed. At least four people were killed in Israel in an Iranian missile barrage. Meanwhile, the Israeli military said it dropped more than 100 munitions on the Iranian capital, Tehran, with massive attacks reported in cities across the country.The 12-day conflict between Israel and Iran killed 610 people in Iran, according to figures released Tuesday by the country’s Health Ministry. The Human Rights Activists News Agency, a Washington-based rights group that monitors Iran, says the death toll is at least 974. In Israel, 28 people were killed in total, the prime minister’s office said in a statement Tuesday.Live coverage contributors 48With much to lose, China sat on Israel-Iran war’s sidelines as U.S. flexedReturn to menuThere was evidence of some Chinese diplomacy this week — Assistant Foreign Minister Liu Bin discussed the Israel-Iran conflict in a meeting with Tehran’s new ambassador to China on Monday, and Chinese officials proposed a U.N. draft resolution for an immediate ceasefire alongside Russia and Pakistan on Sunday. But ultimately, it was the United States that emerged as the region’s primary power broker this week.This is an excerpt from a full story.Imagery shows new damage to Fordow nuclear site and in TehranReturn to menuSatellite imagery shows new damage to the Fordow uranium enrichment facility after Israel targeted the site Monday. The airstrikes came one day after the U.S. dropped “bunker-busting” Massive Ordnance Penetrators, or MOPs, on the site Sunday. According to a senior analyst at the satellite imagery firm Maxar, several buildings were destroyed, and multiple craters are visible at tunnel openings and on access roads that lead to the underground complex.Where are the world’s nuclear weapons, and who owns them?Return to menuPresident Donald Trump claims to have “obliterated” Iran’s nuclear facilities after ordering attacks on three sites this past weekend — even as questions remain about the impact of the strikes and how much they could have delayed Iran from producing a nuclear weapon. Nine countries, including the United States and Israel, are thought to own nuclear weapons. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), which researches arms control, warned this month that a new nuclear arms race could be on the horizon.This is an excerpt from a full story.We texted 1,000 Americans about Trump’s Iran strikes. This is how they responded.Return to menuWhat do Americans think about the airstrikes on Iran nuclear facilities ordered by President Donald Trump this past weekend? How have their opinions shifted since before the U.S. attack? The Washington Post texted more than 1,000 people Monday night to ask.This is an excerpt from a full story.U.S. initial damage report: Iran nuclear program set back by months, not obliterated Return to menuAn initial U.S. intelligence report assesses that airstrikes ordered by President Donald Trump against Iran’s nuclear facilities set Tehran’s program back by months but did not eliminate it, contradicting claims by Trump and his top aides about the mission’s success, according to two people familiar with the report.This is an excerpt from a full story.Post Reports: Netanyahu’s long game in IranReturn to menuOn today’s episode of Post Reports: Jerusalem Bureau Chief Gerry Shih explains that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s long march to war with Iran was months in the making. He tells us why Netanyahu attacked Iran when he did, and what he may have gained politically in the process.Podcast episodeIsrael’s Bedouin rely on makeshift shelters when missiles fallReturn to menuAL-FURA’A, Israel — Most Israeli citizens live within dashing distance of an air raid shelter, but Bedouin in remote, poor villages usually have nothing but what they can rig themselves. One family spent the nights of conflict between Israel and Iran crowded under the bed of a dump truck that had been flipped over and buried in the sand.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuIsrael’s main airport, Ben Gurion International, is set to restart operations after nationwide restrictions were lifted following the news of a ceasefire with Iran. “Restrictions on the number of incoming and outgoing flights, as well as the number of passengers on each flight, have been lifted,” the Israel Airports Authority said in a statement to local media. El Al, Israel’s flag carrier, plans to add additional flights to help return those stranded abroad during the conflict, Reuters reported.Iran attempts to contain fallout after Qatar attackReturn to menuA day after launching an attack on Qatar, Iran worked Tuesday to contain the diplomatic fallout, with calls between the Iranian president, Qatar’s emir and other leaders of its Persian Gulf neighbors.While the attack has strained Iran’s relations with the Arab gulf monarchies, it’s unlikely to derail the newly strengthened ties in the region, according to analysts and officials.Following ‘achievements’ in Iran, IDF says focus must return to GazaReturn to menuAs Israel moved closer to a state of normalcy under a tenuous ceasefire with Iran, Israel Defense Forces chief Eyal Zamir celebrated the “phenomenal achievements” of Israel’s 12-day war with Iran and vowed to return the military’s attention to Gaza.“We must stay focused; there’s no time to rest on our laurels. Now the focus shifts back to Gaza — to bring the hostages home and to dismantle the Hamas regime,” Zamir said Tuesday in remarks to the IDF staff.Return to menuIn a televised statement Tuesday night, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the morning’s attack on Iran ahead of the ceasefire eliminated "hundreds of regime operatives in the most crushing strike Tehran has seen in the past 50 years.”Israel said previously that it had dropped more than 100 munitions on Tehran overnight. Iran has not said how many casualties it suffered, and the Israeli figures has not been verified independently.Netanyahu declared the 12-day conflict against Iran a “victory that will be remembered for generations."If Iran should seek to revive the nuclear project, Netanyahu said, Israel would “act with the same determination and force to thwart any such attempt.”House votes against taking up Trump impeachment over Iran strikeReturn to menuA majority of the House rejected a resolution to impeach President Donald Trump over his decision to strike Iran.Some 128 Democrats joined 216 Republicans to table, or kill, the impeachment resolution that Rep. Al Green (D-Texas) introduced Tuesday afternoon, while 78 Democrats — many from the Congressional Progressive Caucus — joined Green in pursuing a vote on the matter.Return to menuIsraeli Defense Minister Katz told Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth in a phone call that Israel would respect the U.S.-announced ceasefire agreement “as long as the other side does,” according to a statement Katz posted to X.Katz said he thanked Hegseth for America’s decision to act with Israel against the Iranian nuclear threat, and “agreed to deepen the close U.S.-Israel security cooperation.”Return to menuIranian President Masoud Pezeshkian announced an official end to the “12-day war” with Israel in a message delivered to the nation via Iranian state news agency IRNA.“Today, after the heroic resistance of our great nation, whose determination makes history, we are witnessing the establishment of a truce,” said Pezeshkian.Trump told Netanyahu U.S. is done using military against Iran, official saysReturn to menuPleased with his military’s performance and ready to flex his diplomatic skills, President Donald Trump called Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and told him the U.S. was done using its military to help Israel in its war with Iran.“Our U.S. military did what we needed to do,” Trump told Netanyahu, according to a senior White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive and private conversations.Return to menuMichal Zaks, 50, was killed alongside her son, Eitan Zaks, 18, and his girlfriend, Noa Bogoslavsky, by the Iranian missile that hit a residential building in Beersheba, Southern Israel, on Tuesday morning, according to a local government notice and Israel’s Channel 12 news. Eitan was an off-duty Israel Defense Forces soldier.House Democrats launch national security task forceReturn to menuAfter a briefing on Iran for House members that was originally scheduled for Tuesday evening was canceled, House Democrats announced that they would be launching a national security task force to counter the Trump administration’s unwillingness to share details over President Donald Trump’s actions in the Middle East.Iranian president commits to U.S.-announced ceasefire, barring Israeli violationsReturn to menuIranian President Masoud Pezeshkian said in a statement Tuesday that Iran would not violate the ceasefire announced by President Donald Trump on Monday following 12 days of hostilities, as long as Israel also respects its terms.“Tehran is ready for talks and to defend the rights of the Iranian people at the negotiation table,” said Pezeshkian, according to Nour News, an outlet affiliated with the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.Israel bombarded Tehran ahead of tenuous ceasefireReturn to menuIsrael unleashed a barrage of airstrikes across Tehran in the hours before a ceasefire announced by President Donald Trump on Monday night was to come into force, targeting key regime facilities and security forces, according to a statement from the Israeli prime minister’s office.Israeli forces used more than 100 munitions in the strikes, Israel Defense Forces spokesman Brig. Gen. Effie Defrin said in a news conference Tuesday.No off-site radiation out of Iran nuclear sites after attacks, U.N. watchdog saysReturn to menuWhile Iranian nuclear facilities were damaged during the U.S. and Israeli strikes over the weekend, there have been “no reports of increased off-site radiation levels,” Rafael Mariano Grossi, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), said Tuesday.Schumer bashes administration’s abrupt cancellation of Iran briefingsReturn to menuSenate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-New York) slammed the Trump administration on June 24 for abruptly canceling congressional briefings on Iran. (Video: The Washington Post)Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-New York) criticized the Trump administration for abruptly canceling congressional briefings on Iran scheduled for Tuesday afternoon.Democrats have been pushing for a briefing on President Donald Trump’s approach to Israel’s war with Iran since last week. Those calls got louder after Trump authorized strikes on several Iranian nuclear facilities over the weekend.Return to menuOn his way to the NATO summit in The Hague, President Donald Trump on June 24 said Iran was "not going to have a nuclear weapon." (Video: The Washington Post)Speaking to reporters Tuesday aboard Air Force One, President Donald Trump said Iran is “not going to have enrichment, and they’re not going to have a nuclear weapon. And they know that.”Trump added that Iran would “get on to being a great trading nation. … They have a lot of oil. And they’re going to do well.” The “last thing on Iran’s mind right now is nuclear weapons,” he said.Return to menuOn his way to the NATO summit in The Hague, President Donald Trump told reporters he does not want to see regime change in Iran, saying it could inflame tensions in the region.“I’d like to see everything calm down as quickly as possible,” he said. “Regime change takes chaos and ideally, we don’t want to see so much chaos.”Effort underway to restart Gaza ceasefire talks, Qatari prime minister saysReturn to menuQatari Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said efforts are ongoing to restart stalled Gaza ceasefire talks between Israel and Hamas.“We will try to look for an opportunity during the next two days to have indirect negotiations between the two parties to reach an agreement,” Mohammed said during a news conference. President Donald Trump seeks to end fighting between Israel and Iran, and Qatar has played a role in mediation of that conflict.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump shared a congratulatory text message apparently sent to him by NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte regarding the U.S. strikes against Iran.In the message, posted by Trump to Truth Social, Rutte said Trump’s decision to strike Iran’s nuclear facilities was “truly extraordinary, and something no one else dared to do.”Return to menuThe International Federation of the Red Cross reported that five staff members have been killed during Israel’s 12-day military campaign against Iran. On Monday, an Iranian-affiliate of the Red Cross reported that Israeli strikes hit a building adjacent to their Tehran headquarters.Trump pursued diplomacy up until Saturday, White House official saysReturn to menuA senior White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive matters of national security, said Monday that Trump was “consistently pursuing diplomatic channels” and did not make the final decision to strike Iran’s nuclear sites until 4 p.m. Saturday.Admiral declines to say if there are plans to send U.S. troops to IranReturn to menuPresident Donald Trump’s nominee to oversee U.S. military operations across the Middle East declined to say whether there are plans to put U.S. troops in Iran and how long the conflict in the region could stretch if the ceasefire brokered Monday falls apart.Vice Adm. Charles “Brad” Cooper, who has been nominated to lead U.S. Central Command, said it would be his obligation if he is confirmed to provide the president with a wide range of options to deal with issues in the region.Return to menuHouse Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana) said he believes the War Powers Act — which dictates that only Congress can declare war — is in violation of the Constitution.“Many respected constitutional experts argue that the War Powers Act is itself unconstitutional,” Johnson told reporters Tuesday. "I’m persuaded by that argument. They think it’s a violation of the Article 2 powers of the commander in chief. I think that’s right.”A bipartisan group of lawmakers in recent days have said they want a vote on the act in order to curb Trump’s actions in Iran.U.S. scrambles to determine impact of strikes on Iran’s nuclear sites Return to menuPresident Donald Trump has proclaimed that the U.S. bombing of Iranian nuclear enrichment facilities was an unmitigated success.U.S. strikes on Iran may have been a tactical win, with all three targets hit and all planes safely returned home. But experts are still trying to determine whether the strikes achieved their stated strategic goal of eliminating Iran’s nuclear program, even as Trump declared late Monday afternoon that Iran and Israel had agreed to end their war.This is an excerpt from a full story.Iran retains ‘significant’ capability to strike U.S. troops, admiral saysReturn to menuA senior military officer nominated by President Donald Trump to lead all U.S. military operations in the Middle East told lawmakers Tuesday that Iran still possesses “significant tactical capability” to strike U.S. troops in the region, including ballistic missiles like the ones used in an attack on a major U.S. military base in Qatar on Monday.U.S. admiral says Iran is diminished, but urges continued scrutinyReturn to menuA senior military officer nominated by President Donald Trump to lead U.S. military operations in the Middle East told lawmakers Tuesday that Iran’s capability to threaten the United States and its allies has been weakened since the Hamas militant attack on Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, but he deferred questions on the specifics until a classified discussion with lawmakers later in the day.Qatar hopes ceasefire holds despite violations, PM saysReturn to menuQatari Prime Minister and Foreign Affairs Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani announced that his country helped broker a ceasefire between Israel and Iran.Israel says it destroyed radar system in response to Iranian missilesReturn to menuThe Israeli Air Force destroyed a radar system near Tehran, the office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Tuesday in a statement, in response to what it described as two Iranian violations of the ceasefire.It said that Netanyahu, following a call with President Donald Trump, has “refrained from further strikes” in Iran.What satellite images reveal about damage to Iran’s nuclear sites Return to menuSatellite images provide the first glimpses of the aftermath of U.S. strikes on three sites said to be central to Iran’s nuclear program, revealing severe damage at aboveground facilities as well as the entry points left by bombs that burrowed deep underground to target some of the program’s most protected operations.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump called Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday and asked him not to send an immediate military strike in response to what Israel said was Iran’s violation of the ceasefire, said a person familiar with the exchange, who spoke on the condition of anonymity in order to discuss sensitive communications.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump said Tuesday that Israel “is not going to attack Iran,” shortly after he accused both countries of violating a ceasefire agreement. “All planes will turn around and head home, while doing a friendly ‘Plane Wave’ to Iran,” Trump wrote on Truth Social. “Nobody will be hurt, the Ceasefire is in effect!” Return to menuIsraeli attacks on Iran killed at least 610 people over 12 days of fighting, Hossein Kermanpour, a Health Ministry spokesperson, said Tuesday. At least 13 of the dead were children, with the youngest 2 months old, he said. More than 4,700 were injured, he added, with 971 still hospitalized. Rights groups have said the ministry’s toll is probably an undercount, with one Washington-based group, Human Rights Activists News Agency, putting the toll at almost 1,000 dead.Trump accuses Israel and Iran of violating ceasefire dealReturn to menuPresident Donald Trump on June 24 used an expletive and accused both Israel and Iran of violating a ceasefire agreement hours after it took effect. (Video: The Washington Post)U.S. President Donald Trump vented his anger at both Israel and Iran on Tuesday, accusing both of violating a ceasefire agreement shortly after it came into effect in the morning, saying the two countries “have been fighting so long and so hard that they don’t know what the f--- they’re doing.”NORAD plans nighttime defense drill over D.C.Return to menuThe U.S. military intends to fly several aircraft, including F-16 fighter jets, over Washington and surrounding areas as part of a nighttime defense exercise scheduled for later this week, officials said Monday.The announcement’s timing has “nothing to do with Iran” or any imminent threat to the nation’s capital, said 2nd Lt. Tyler Turnmire, a spokesman for the North American Aerospace Defense Command’s 601st Air Operations Center.Return to menuRussian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said that Russia welcomed a ceasefire between Israel and Iran but that it is difficult to get a “definitive picture” of its durability. Speaking at an international relations forum Tuesday, Lavrov said: “On the one hand, U.S. President Donald Trump declared peace between Iran and Israel, and on the other, this statement was followed by reports on continuing hostilities in the conflict zone, which suggests that it would be premature to make any conclusions in this situation.” Russia is “in favor of peace,” he added.Return to menuIranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Esmaeil Baqaei said Iran’s strike Monday on a U.S. military base in Qatar was self-defense against “unprovoked aggression” and that his country remains committed to “good neighborliness” with Qatar and others in the region. “This act of self-defense had nothing to do with our friendly neighbor Qatar as we enjoy excellent and deeply rooted relationships,” he said Tuesday in a post on X, in reference to an Iranian strike against the American al-Udeid base that came after U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities. “We resolve not to let U.S./Israeli criminal aggressions and malign policies against Iran create division between us and the brotherly countries of the region,” he wrote.World leaders call for ceasefire to be respectedReturn to menuWorld leaders welcomed news of a ceasefire deal between Iran and Israel early Tuesday and called for further de-escalation, even as the ceasefire appeared off to a shaky start.Several leaders’ statements on the ceasefire came before or around the same time as Israeli accusations of an Iranian missile launch — which Iran denied — and it was unclear whether their statements were prepared beforehand.House Democratic committee leaders introduce War Powers ResolutionReturn to menuThree House Democratic committee leaders have introduced a War Powers Resolution that would limit President Donald Trump from escalating a conflict with Iran without congressional approval.Exclusive: Israel warned top Iranian general, officials amid June 13 strikesReturn to menuThe Washington Post obtained the audio file of an Israeli intelligence operative’s June 13 call to a senior Iranian commander. (Video: HyoJung Kim, Zoeann Murphy/The Washington Post)In the hours after Israel launched its first wave of strikes against Iran on June 13, killing top military leaders and nuclear scientists, Israeli intelligence operatives launched a covert campaign to intimidate senior officials with the apparent aim of dividing and destabilizing Tehran’s theocratic regime, according to three people familiar with the operation.This is an excerpt from a full story.Katz accuses Iran of missile launch, which Iran deniesReturn to menuWp logoThe Israel Defense Forces accused Iran of missile fire Tuesday, shortly after Iran and Israel appeared to agree to a cessation of fighting. Shortly after, Iran’s state broadcaster said on its Telegram channel that claims of missiles being launched from Iran were false, citing Iran’s General Staff of the Armed Forces.Israel’s Defense Minister Israel Katz said he instructed the IDF to “respond forcefully to Iran’s violation of the ceasefire” with strikes against Iranian regime targets in Tehran.Iran offered blueprint for ceasefire deal, says U.S. official Return to menuThe blueprint for Monday’s ceasefire agreement came from discussions with Iranian officials, who made clear to the Trump administration that they would come back to the negotiating table and discuss their nuclear program on the condition that Israel stops bombing them, according to a senior U.S. official speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive diplomatic matters.Return to menuThe ceasefire deal was coordinated at the highest level by U.S. President Donald Trump and Vice President JD Vance, along with Qatari Emir Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani and Prime Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani directly, according to a diplomat briefed on the matter, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive diplomacy.Return to menuBefore the ceasefire’s start, Israel carried out strikes on Iran overnight, with the Israel Defense Forces ordering citizens to evacuate parts of two neighborhoods in Tehran Monday evening. Loud explosions were heard in parts of Tehran, Iran’s state media, Islamic Republic News Agency, reported. The IDF said early Tuesday that it attacked and destroyed missile launchers in western Tehran.Return to menuIsraeli military spokesman Effie Defrin said in a televised statement that forces would remain on high alert for any violation of the ceasefire and that Israel had “achieved all the objectives” of its operation in Iran. In what appeared to be a blistering last-minute attack before the ceasefire came into effect, Israel dropped over 100 munitions on Tehran, Defrin said.Photos show destruction of building in Beersheba, IsraelReturn to menuBEERSHEBA, Israel — At the scene of a strike during an Iranian missile barrage in Beersheba on Tuesday morning, rescue workers and members of the Israel Defense Forces examined the rubble of a seven-story residential building. A body bag was lowered to emergency workers waiting in a parking lot.Return to menuThe Hostages and Missing Families Forum in Israel has called for the Iran-Israel ceasefire agreement to expand to include Gaza and to secure the return of all hostages. “Those who can achieve a ceasefire with Iran can also end the war in Gaza,” it said in a statement Tuesday. “The Israeli government has a duty to seize this opportunity with both hands, and pursue with full force a comprehensive deal that will return all 50 hostages in one phase and end the war.”Return to menuRescue efforts were underway in Beersheba, Israel, after a residential building was hit June 24, hours before a ceasefire between Israel and Iran took effect. (Video: Heidi Levine/The Washington Post)At least four people were killed in southern Israel in Iran’s early-morning missile barrages, Magen David Adom, Israel’s emergency services, said. There were multiple waves of missile fire, according to the Israel Defense Forces, which issued its latest all-clear to leave shelters at 7.45 a.m. local time.Return to menuPresident Donald Trump said in a social media post at 1:08 a.m. Tuesday that the ceasefire between Israel and Iran was now in effect. “Please do not violate it,” he wrote.Trump claims ceasefire between Iran, Israel after attack on U.S. baseReturn to menuIran's military said on June 23 that it carried out a missile attack on al-Udeid Air Base in Qatar. (Video: Reuters)ISTANBUL — President Donald Trump claimed in a social media post Monday that Iran and Israel had agreed to a ceasefire, hours after Iran fired missiles toward an American air base in Qatar retaliating for U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities with a serious attack that caused no casualties.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuIsrael has agreed to the ceasefire proposed by President Donald Trump, it said Tuesday morning. In a statement, the government said it had achieved its military objectives against Iran. “Israel thanks President Trump and the United States for their support in defense and for their participation in removing the Iranian nuclear threat,” the statement said, adding that any ceasefire violations will be met with force.
html:
A ceasefire between Israel and Iran appears to be holding, after an initial shaky period in which both sides accused each other of violations, drawing admonishment from President Donald Trump. “Both Israel and Iran wanted to stop the War, equally!” Trump wrote in a post on Truth Social on Tuesday, en route to a NATO summit in the Netherlands. “It was my great honor to Destroy All Nuclear facilities & capability, and then, STOP THE WAR!” An initial U.S. intelligence report cast doubt on Trump’s claims, however, assessing that U.S. airstrikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities set Tehran’s program back by months but did not eliminate it, two people familiar with the report told the Post.

Where things stand: Ceasefire, latest strikes and the war’s death toll

Return to menu

  • Israel and Iran have publicly committed to upholding a ceasefire that President Donald Trump announced Monday evening, with both sides casting it as a victory to their people.
  • Trump told Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that the United States was done using its military to help Israel in its war with Iran, according to a senior White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive and private conversations.
  • In the hours after the ceasefire had been expected to go into effect early Tuesday, Israel and Iran accused each other of violating the agreement, drawing admonishment from Trump. Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz accused Iran of firing a wave of missiles toward Israel and said he instructed the military to “respond forcefully.” A message posted on the Telegram channel of Iran’s state broadcaster denied the claim of a missile launch. Iran then accused Israel of launching three waves of attacks shortly after Trump said the truce had gone into effect. Netanyahu’s office later said Israel would refrain from additional attacks.
  • A preliminary U.S. intelligence report assessed that U.S. airstrikes against Iran’s nuclear facilities set Tehran’s program back by months but did not eliminate it like Trump had announced, two people familiar with the report told The Washington Post.
  • The International Atomic Energy Agency director general Rafael Mariano Grossi said there were no reports of increased off-site radiation levels around the nuclear facilities.
  • Israel and Iran launched blistering attacks on each other as a deadline for the truce loomed. At least four people were killed in Israel in an Iranian missile barrage. Meanwhile, the Israeli military said it dropped more than 100 munitions on the Iranian capital, Tehran, with massive attacks reported in cities across the country.
  • The 12-day conflict between Israel and Iran killed 610 people in Iran, according to figures released Tuesday by the country’s Health Ministry. The Human Rights Activists News Agency, a Washington-based rights group that monitors Iran, says the death toll is at least 974. In Israel, 28 people were killed in total, the prime minister’s office said in a statement Tuesday.

Live coverage contributors 48

  • With much to lose, China sat on Israel-Iran war’s sidelines as U.S. flexed

    Return to menu

    There was evidence of some Chinese diplomacy this week — Assistant Foreign Minister Liu Bin discussed the Israel-Iran conflict in a meeting with Tehran’s new ambassador to China on Monday, and Chinese officials proposed a U.N. draft resolution for an immediate ceasefire alongside Russia and Pakistan on Sunday. But ultimately, it was the United States that emerged as the region’s primary power broker this week.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Imagery shows new damage to Fordow nuclear site and in Tehran

    Return to menu

    Satellite imagery shows new damage to the Fordow uranium enrichment facility after Israel targeted the site Monday. The airstrikes came one day after the U.S. dropped “bunker-busting” Massive Ordnance Penetrators, or MOPs, on the site Sunday. According to a senior analyst at the satellite imagery firm Maxar, several buildings were destroyed, and multiple craters are visible at tunnel openings and on access roads that lead to the underground complex.

  • Where are the world’s nuclear weapons, and who owns them?

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump claims to have “obliterated” Iran’s nuclear facilities after ordering attacks on three sites this past weekend — even as questions remain about the impact of the strikes and how much they could have delayed Iran from producing a nuclear weapon. Nine countries, including the United States and Israel, are thought to own nuclear weapons. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), which researches arms control, warned this month that a new nuclear arms race could be on the horizon.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • We texted 1,000 Americans about Trump’s Iran strikes. This is how they responded.

    Return to menu

    What do Americans think about the airstrikes on Iran nuclear facilities ordered by President Donald Trump this past weekend? How have their opinions shifted since before the U.S. attack? The Washington Post texted more than 1,000 people Monday night to ask.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • U.S. initial damage report: Iran nuclear program set back by months, not obliterated

    Return to menu

    An initial U.S. intelligence report assesses that airstrikes ordered by President Donald Trump against Iran’s nuclear facilities set Tehran’s program back by months but did not eliminate it, contradicting claims by Trump and his top aides about the mission’s success, according to two people familiar with the report.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Post Reports: Netanyahu’s long game in Iran

    Return to menu

    On today’s episode of Post Reports: Jerusalem Bureau Chief Gerry Shih explains that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s long march to war with Iran was months in the making. He tells us why Netanyahu attacked Iran when he did, and what he may have gained politically in the process.

    Podcast episode

  • Israel’s Bedouin rely on makeshift shelters when missiles fall

    Return to menu

    AL-FURA’A, Israel — Most Israeli citizens live within dashing distance of an air raid shelter, but Bedouin in remote, poor villages usually have nothing but what they can rig themselves. One family spent the nights of conflict between Israel and Iran crowded under the bed of a dump truck that had been flipped over and buried in the sand.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    Israel’s main airport, Ben Gurion International, is set to restart operations after nationwide restrictions were lifted following the news of a ceasefire with Iran. “Restrictions on the number of incoming and outgoing flights, as well as the number of passengers on each flight, have been lifted,” the Israel Airports Authority said in a statement to local media. El Al, Israel’s flag carrier, plans to add additional flights to help return those stranded abroad during the conflict, Reuters reported.

  • Iran attempts to contain fallout after Qatar attack

    Return to menu

    A day after launching an attack on Qatar, Iran worked Tuesday to contain the diplomatic fallout, with calls between the Iranian president, Qatar’s emir and other leaders of its Persian Gulf neighbors.

    While the attack has strained Iran’s relations with the Arab gulf monarchies, it’s unlikely to derail the newly strengthened ties in the region, according to analysts and officials.

  • Following ‘achievements’ in Iran, IDF says focus must return to Gaza

    Return to menu

    As Israel moved closer to a state of normalcy under a tenuous ceasefire with Iran, Israel Defense Forces chief Eyal Zamir celebrated the “phenomenal achievements” of Israel’s 12-day war with Iran and vowed to return the military’s attention to Gaza.

    “We must stay focused; there’s no time to rest on our laurels. Now the focus shifts back to Gaza — to bring the hostages home and to dismantle the Hamas regime,” Zamir said Tuesday in remarks to the IDF staff.

  • Return to menu

    In a televised statement Tuesday night, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the morning’s attack on Iran ahead of the ceasefire eliminated "hundreds of regime operatives in the most crushing strike Tehran has seen in the past 50 years.”

    Israel said previously that it had dropped more than 100 munitions on Tehran overnight. Iran has not said how many casualties it suffered, and the Israeli figures has not been verified independently.

    Netanyahu declared the 12-day conflict against Iran a “victory that will be remembered for generations."

    If Iran should seek to revive the nuclear project, Netanyahu said, Israel would “act with the same determination and force to thwart any such attempt.”

  • House votes against taking up Trump impeachment over Iran strike

    Return to menu

    A majority of the House rejected a resolution to impeach President Donald Trump over his decision to strike Iran.

    Some 128 Democrats joined 216 Republicans to table, or kill, the impeachment resolution that Rep. Al Green (D-Texas) introduced Tuesday afternoon, while 78 Democrats — many from the Congressional Progressive Caucus — joined Green in pursuing a vote on the matter.

  • Return to menu

    Israeli Defense Minister Katz told Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth in a phone call that Israel would respect the U.S.-announced ceasefire agreement “as long as the other side does,” according to a statement Katz posted to X.

    Katz said he thanked Hegseth for America’s decision to act with Israel against the Iranian nuclear threat, and “agreed to deepen the close U.S.-Israel security cooperation.”

  • Return to menu

    Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian announced an official end to the “12-day war” with Israel in a message delivered to the nation via Iranian state news agency IRNA.

    “Today, after the heroic resistance of our great nation, whose determination makes history, we are witnessing the establishment of a truce,” said Pezeshkian.

  • Trump told Netanyahu U.S. is done using military against Iran, official says

    Return to menu

    Pleased with his military’s performance and ready to flex his diplomatic skills, President Donald Trump called Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and told him the U.S. was done using its military to help Israel in its war with Iran.

    “Our U.S. military did what we needed to do,” Trump told Netanyahu, according to a senior White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive and private conversations.

    Michal Zaks, 50, was killed alongside her son, Eitan Zaks, 18, and his girlfriend, Noa Bogoslavsky, by the Iranian missile that hit a residential building in Beersheba, Southern Israel, on Tuesday morning, according to a local government notice and Israel’s Channel 12 news. Eitan was an off-duty Israel Defense Forces soldier.

  • House Democrats launch national security task force

    Return to menu

    After a briefing on Iran for House members that was originally scheduled for Tuesday evening was canceled, House Democrats announced that they would be launching a national security task force to counter the Trump administration’s unwillingness to share details over President Donald Trump’s actions in the Middle East.

  • Iranian president commits to U.S.-announced ceasefire, barring Israeli violations

    Return to menu

    Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian said in a statement Tuesday that Iran would not violate the ceasefire announced by President Donald Trump on Monday following 12 days of hostilities, as long as Israel also respects its terms.

    “Tehran is ready for talks and to defend the rights of the Iranian people at the negotiation table,” said Pezeshkian, according to Nour News, an outlet affiliated with the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.

  • Israel bombarded Tehran ahead of tenuous ceasefire

    Return to menu

    Israel unleashed a barrage of airstrikes across Tehran in the hours before a ceasefire announced by President Donald Trump on Monday night was to come into force, targeting key regime facilities and security forces, according to a statement from the Israeli prime minister’s office.

    Israeli forces used more than 100 munitions in the strikes, Israel Defense Forces spokesman Brig. Gen. Effie Defrin said in a news conference Tuesday.

  • No off-site radiation out of Iran nuclear sites after attacks, U.N. watchdog says

    Return to menu

    While Iranian nuclear facilities were damaged during the U.S. and Israeli strikes over the weekend, there have been “no reports of increased off-site radiation levels,” Rafael Mariano Grossi, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), said Tuesday.

  • Schumer bashes administration’s abrupt cancellation of Iran briefings

    Return to menu

    Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-New York) criticized the Trump administration for abruptly canceling congressional briefings on Iran scheduled for Tuesday afternoon.

    Democrats have been pushing for a briefing on President Donald Trump’s approach to Israel’s war with Iran since last week. Those calls got louder after Trump authorized strikes on several Iranian nuclear facilities over the weekend.

  • Return to menu

    Speaking to reporters Tuesday aboard Air Force One, President Donald Trump said Iran is “not going to have enrichment, and they’re not going to have a nuclear weapon. And they know that.”

    Trump added that Iran would “get on to being a great trading nation. … They have a lot of oil. And they’re going to do well.” The “last thing on Iran’s mind right now is nuclear weapons,” he said.

  • Return to menu

    On his way to the NATO summit in The Hague, President Donald Trump told reporters he does not want to see regime change in Iran, saying it could inflame tensions in the region.

    “I’d like to see everything calm down as quickly as possible,” he said. “Regime change takes chaos and ideally, we don’t want to see so much chaos.”

  • Effort underway to restart Gaza ceasefire talks, Qatari prime minister says

    Return to menu

    Qatari Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said efforts are ongoing to restart stalled Gaza ceasefire talks between Israel and Hamas.

    “We will try to look for an opportunity during the next two days to have indirect negotiations between the two parties to reach an agreement,” Mohammed said during a news conference. President Donald Trump seeks to end fighting between Israel and Iran, and Qatar has played a role in mediation of that conflict.

  • Return to menu

    President Donald Trump shared a congratulatory text message apparently sent to him by NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte regarding the U.S. strikes against Iran.

    In the message, posted by Trump to Truth Social, Rutte said Trump’s decision to strike Iran’s nuclear facilities was “truly extraordinary, and something no one else dared to do.”

    The International Federation of the Red Cross reported that five staff members have been killed during Israel’s 12-day military campaign against Iran. On Monday, an Iranian-affiliate of the Red Cross reported that Israeli strikes hit a building adjacent to their Tehran headquarters.

  • Trump pursued diplomacy up until Saturday, White House official says

    Return to menu

    A senior White House official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive matters of national security, said Monday that Trump was “consistently pursuing diplomatic channels” and did not make the final decision to strike Iran’s nuclear sites until 4 p.m. Saturday.

  • Admiral declines to say if there are plans to send U.S. troops to Iran

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump’s nominee to oversee U.S. military operations across the Middle East declined to say whether there are plans to put U.S. troops in Iran and how long the conflict in the region could stretch if the ceasefire brokered Monday falls apart.

    Vice Adm. Charles “Brad” Cooper, who has been nominated to lead U.S. Central Command, said it would be his obligation if he is confirmed to provide the president with a wide range of options to deal with issues in the region.

  • Return to menu

    House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana) said he believes the War Powers Act — which dictates that only Congress can declare war — is in violation of the Constitution.

    “Many respected constitutional experts argue that the War Powers Act is itself unconstitutional,” Johnson told reporters Tuesday. "I’m persuaded by that argument. They think it’s a violation of the Article 2 powers of the commander in chief. I think that’s right.”

    A bipartisan group of lawmakers in recent days have said they want a vote on the act in order to curb Trump’s actions in Iran.

  • U.S. scrambles to determine impact of strikes on Iran’s nuclear sites

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump has proclaimed that the U.S. bombing of Iranian nuclear enrichment facilities was an unmitigated success.

    U.S. strikes on Iran may have been a tactical win, with all three targets hit and all planes safely returned home. But experts are still trying to determine whether the strikes achieved their stated strategic goal of eliminating Iran’s nuclear program, even as Trump declared late Monday afternoon that Iran and Israel had agreed to end their war.

    A senior military officer nominated by President Donald Trump to lead all U.S. military operations in the Middle East told lawmakers Tuesday that Iran still possesses “significant tactical capability” to strike U.S. troops in the region, including ballistic missiles like the ones used in an attack on a major U.S. military base in Qatar on Monday.

  • U.S. admiral says Iran is diminished, but urges continued scrutiny

    A senior military officer nominated by President Donald Trump to lead U.S. military operations in the Middle East told lawmakers Tuesday that Iran’s capability to threaten the United States and its allies has been weakened since the Hamas militant attack on Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, but he deferred questions on the specifics until a classified discussion with lawmakers later in the day.

    Satellite images provide the first glimpses of the aftermath of U.S. strikes on three sites said to be central to Iran’s nuclear program, revealing severe damage at aboveground facilities as well as the entry points left by bombs that burrowed deep underground to target some of the program’s most protected operations.

    President Donald Trump called Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday and asked him not to send an immediate military strike in response to what Israel said was Iran’s violation of the ceasefire, said a person familiar with the exchange, who spoke on the condition of anonymity in order to discuss sensitive communications.

  • Return to menu

    President Donald Trump said Tuesday that Israel “is not going to attack Iran,” shortly after he accused both countries of violating a ceasefire agreement. “All planes will turn around and head home, while doing a friendly ‘Plane Wave’ to Iran,” Trump wrote on Truth Social. “Nobody will be hurt, the Ceasefire is in effect!”

  • Return to menu

    Israeli attacks on Iran killed at least 610 people over 12 days of fighting, Hossein Kermanpour, a Health Ministry spokesperson, said Tuesday. At least 13 of the dead were children, with the youngest 2 months old, he said. More than 4,700 were injured, he added, with 971 still hospitalized. Rights groups have said the ministry’s toll is probably an undercount, with one Washington-based group, Human Rights Activists News Agency, putting the toll at almost 1,000 dead.

  • Trump accuses Israel and Iran of violating ceasefire deal

    Return to menu

    U.S. President Donald Trump vented his anger at both Israel and Iran on Tuesday, accusing both of violating a ceasefire agreement shortly after it came into effect in the morning, saying the two countries “have been fighting so long and so hard that they don’t know what the f--- they’re doing.”

  • NORAD plans nighttime defense drill over D.C.

    The U.S. military intends to fly several aircraft, including F-16 fighter jets, over Washington and surrounding areas as part of a nighttime defense exercise scheduled for later this week, officials said Monday.

    The announcement’s timing has “nothing to do with Iran” or any imminent threat to the nation’s capital, said 2nd Lt. Tyler Turnmire, a spokesman for the North American Aerospace Defense Command’s 601st Air Operations Center.

    Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said that Russia welcomed a ceasefire between Israel and Iran but that it is difficult to get a “definitive picture” of its durability. Speaking at an international relations forum Tuesday, Lavrov said: “On the one hand, U.S. President Donald Trump declared peace between Iran and Israel, and on the other, this statement was followed by reports on continuing hostilities in the conflict zone, which suggests that it would be premature to make any conclusions in this situation.” Russia is “in favor of peace,” he added.

    Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Esmaeil Baqaei said Iran’s strike Monday on a U.S. military base in Qatar was self-defense against “unprovoked aggression” and that his country remains committed to “good neighborliness” with Qatar and others in the region. “This act of self-defense had nothing to do with our friendly neighbor Qatar as we enjoy excellent and deeply rooted relationships,” he said Tuesday in a post on X, in reference to an Iranian strike against the American al-Udeid base that came after U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities. “We resolve not to let U.S./Israeli criminal aggressions and malign policies against Iran create division between us and the brotherly countries of the region,” he wrote.

    World leaders welcomed news of a ceasefire deal between Iran and Israel early Tuesday and called for further de-escalation, even as the ceasefire appeared off to a shaky start.

    Several leaders’ statements on the ceasefire came before or around the same time as Israeli accusations of an Iranian missile launch — which Iran denied — and it was unclear whether their statements were prepared beforehand.

    The Israel Defense Forces accused Iran of missile fire Tuesday, shortly after Iran and Israel appeared to agree to a cessation of fighting. Shortly after, Iran’s state broadcaster said on its Telegram channel that claims of missiles being launched from Iran were false, citing Iran’s General Staff of the Armed Forces.

    Israel’s Defense Minister Israel Katz said he instructed the IDF to “respond forcefully to Iran’s violation of the ceasefire” with strikes against Iranian regime targets in Tehran.

    The blueprint for Monday’s ceasefire agreement came from discussions with Iranian officials, who made clear to the Trump administration that they would come back to the negotiating table and discuss their nuclear program on the condition that Israel stops bombing them, according to a senior U.S. official speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive diplomatic matters.

    The ceasefire deal was coordinated at the highest level by U.S. President Donald Trump and Vice President JD Vance, along with Qatari Emir Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani and Prime Minister Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani directly, according to a diplomat briefed on the matter, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive diplomacy.

    Before the ceasefire’s start, Israel carried out strikes on Iran overnight, with the Israel Defense Forces ordering citizens to evacuate parts of two neighborhoods in Tehran Monday evening. Loud explosions were heard in parts of Tehran, Iran’s state media, Islamic Republic News Agency, reported. The IDF said early Tuesday that it attacked and destroyed missile launchers in western Tehran.

    Israeli military spokesman Effie Defrin said in a televised statement that forces would remain on high alert for any violation of the ceasefire and that Israel had “achieved all the objectives” of its operation in Iran. In what appeared to be a blistering last-minute attack before the ceasefire came into effect, Israel dropped over 100 munitions on Tehran, Defrin said.

A body bag was lowered to emergency workers waiting in a parking lot.

    The Hostages and Missing Families Forum in Israel has called for the Iran-Israel ceasefire agreement to expand to include Gaza and to secure the return of all hostages. “Those who can achieve a ceasefire with Iran can also end the war in Gaza,” it said in a statement Tuesday. “The Israeli government has a duty to seize this opportunity with both hands, and pursue with full force a comprehensive deal that will return all 50 hostages in one phase and end the war.”

    At least four people were killed in southern Israel in Iran’s early-morning missile barrages, Magen David Adom, Israel’s emergency services, said. There were multiple waves of missile fire, according to the Israel Defense Forces, which issued its latest all-clear to leave shelters at 7.45 a.m. local time.

    President Donald Trump said in a social media post at 1:08 a.m. Tuesday that the ceasefire between Israel and Iran was now in effect. “Please do not violate it,” he wrote.

    Israel has agreed to the ceasefire proposed by President Donald Trump, it said Tuesday morning. In a statement, the government said it had achieved its military objectives against Iran. “Israel thanks President Trump and the United States for their support in defense and for their participation in removing the Iranian nuclear threat,” the statement said, adding that any ceasefire violations will be met with force.
